edu.purdue.jsysnet.util
Class Correlation

java.lang.Object
  edu.purdue.jsysnet.util.Correlation

public class Correlation
extends Object

A class for connecting two Molecules and determining their correlation coefficient.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Thomas McGrew

setDefaultMethod

public static boolean setDefaultMethod(int method)
Sets the default calculation method for all Correlations.

Parameters:
method - The method to be used.
Returns:
true on success, false on failure.

getMolecules

public Molecule[] getMolecules()
Gets the Molecules associated with this Correlation.

Returns:
A Molecule array of length 2, containing the 2 Molecules associated with this correlation.

getOpposite

public Molecule getOpposite(Molecule molecule)
Returns the other molecule in this Correlation

Parameters:
molecule - The Molecule you wish to get the opposite of.
Returns:
The opposite Molecule from the passed in Molecule which is assiciated with this correlation. Returns null if the passed in Molecule is not associated with this Correlation.

Parameters:
molecule - The molecule to test association with.
Returns:
True if this Correlation is associated with the specified Molecule, false otherwise.

getValue

public double getValue()
Gets the correlation coefficient of this Correlation.

Returns:
A double containing the last calculated correlation coeficcient. Defaults to PEARSON.

getValue

public double getValue(int method)
Gets the correlation coeffiecient of this Correlation

Parameters:
method - The coefficient calculation method to use. Should be one of Correlation.PEARSON, Correlation.SPEARMAN, or Correlation.KENDALL.
Returns:
A double containing the requested correlation value.

Parameters:

getPearsonCorrelation

public double getPearsonCorrelation()
Returns the Pearson correlation coefficient of the 2 molecueles. x = sample values in molecule 0 y = sample values in molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Sx = standard deviation of x Sy = standard deviation of y 
                                               _              _
                     sum( i=0 to n-1, ( x[i] - x ) * ( y[i] - y ))
 correlationValue = -----------------------------------------------
                                ( n - 1 ) Sx * Sy
Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation#Pearson.27s_product-moment_coefficient

Returns:
The Pearson correlation value.

getPearsonCorrelation

public double getPearsonCorrelation(boolean recalc)
Returns the Pearson correlation coefficient of the 2 molecueles. x = sample values in molecule 0 y = sample values in molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Sx = standard deviation of x Sy = standard deviation of y 
                                               _              _
                     sum( i=0 to n-1, ( x[i] - x ) * ( y[i] - y ))
 correlationValue = -----------------------------------------------
                                ( n - 1 ) Sx * Sy
Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation#Pearson.27s_product-moment_coefficient

Parameters:
recalc - True if you want the value recalculated, otherwise a cached value will be returned if present.
Returns:
The Pearson correlation value.

 correlationValue = -----------------------------------------------

getPearsonCorrelation

public static double getPearsonCorrelation(List<Double> x,
                                           List<Double> y)
Returns the Pearson correlation coefficient of the 2 sets of values. x = sample values in molecule 0 y = sample values in molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Sx = standard deviation of x Sy = standard deviation of y 
                                               _              _
                     sum( i=0 to n-1, ( x[i] - x ) * ( y[i] - y ))
 correlationValue = -----------------------------------------------
                                ( n - 1 ) Sx * Sy
Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation#Pearson.27s_product-moment_coefficient

Parameters:
x - The first set of values to use for the calculation.
y - The second set of values to use for the calculation.
Returns:
The Pearson correlation value.

getSpearmanCorrelation

public double getSpearmanCorrelation()
Returns the Spearman rank correlation coefficient of the 2 molecules. x = sample values in molecule 0 y = sample values in molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Rx = rank array of x, ie. the new locations of each element of x if x were sorted (starting at 1). Ry = rank array of y, ie. the new locations of each element of y if y were sorted ( starting at 1) 
                         6 * sum( i=0 to n-1, ( Rx[i] - Ry[i] )^2 )
 correlationValue = 1 - --------------------------------------------
                                       n * ( n^2 - 1 )
Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spearman_correlation

Returns:
The Spearman correlation value.

getSpearmanCorrelation

public double getSpearmanCorrelation(boolean recalc)
Returns the Spearman rank correlation coefficient of the 2 molecules. x = sample values in molecule 0 y = sample values in molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Rx = rank array of x, ie. the new locations of each element of x if x were sorted (starting at 1). Ry = rank array of y, ie. the new locations of each element of y if y were sorted ( starting at 1) 
                         6 * sum( i=0 to n-1, ( Rx[i] - Ry[i] )^2 )
 correlationValue = 1 - --------------------------------------------
                                       n * ( n^2 - 1 )
Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spearman_correlation

Parameters:
recalc - True if you want the value recalculated, otherwise a cached value will be returned if present.
Returns:
The Spearman correlation value.

getSpearmanCorrelation

public static double getSpearmanCorrelation(Molecule molecule0,
                                            Molecule molecule1)
Returns the Spearman rank correlation coefficient of the 2 molecules. x = sample values in molecule 0 y = sample values in molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Rx = rank array of x, ie. the new locations of each element of x if x were sorted (starting at 1). Ry = rank array of y, ie. the new locations of each element of y if y were sorted ( starting at 1) 
                         6 * sum( i=0 to n-1, ( Rx[i] - Ry[i] )^2 )
 correlationValue = 1 - --------------------------------------------
                                       n * ( n^2 - 1 )
Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spearman_correlation

Parameters:
molecule0 - The first Molecule to use for the calculation.
molecule1 - The second Molecule to use for the calculation.
Returns:
The Spearman correlation value.

getSpearmanCorrelation

public static double getSpearmanCorrelation(List<Double> x,
                                            List<Double> y)
Returns the Spearman rank correlation coefficient of the 2 sets of data. x = sample values in molecule 0 y = sample values in molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Rx = rank array of x, ie. the new locations of each element of x if x were sorted (starting at 1). Ry = rank array of y, ie. the new locations of each element of y if y were sorted ( starting at 1) 
                         6 * sum( i=0 to n-1, ( Rx[i] - Ry[i] )^2 )
 correlationValue = 1 - --------------------------------------------
                                       n * ( n^2 - 1 )
Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spearman_correlation

Parameters:
x - The first set of data to use for the calculation.
y - The second set of data to use for the calculation.
Returns:
The Spearman correlation value.

getKendallCorrelation

public double getKendallCorrelation()
Returns the Kendall tau rank correlation coefficient of the 2 molecules. x = sample values of molecule 0 y = sample values of molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Rx = the rank of the samples in molecule 0 Ry = the rank of the samples in molecule 1 concordant = The number of concordant pairs discordant = The number of discordant pairs concordant - discordant correlationValue = ----------------------------- (1/2) * pairs * ( pairs-1 ) Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kendall_tau_rank_correlation_coefficient

Returns:
The Kendall tau correlation value.

getKendallCorrelation

public double getKendallCorrelation(boolean recalc)
Returns the Kendall tau rank correlation coefficient of the 2 molecules. x = sample values of molecule 0 y = sample values of molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Rx = the rank of the samples in molecule 0 Ry = the rank of the samples in molecule 1 concordant = The number of concordant pairs discordant = The number of discordant pairs concordant - discordant correlationValue = ----------------------------- (1/2) * pairs * ( pairs-1 ) Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kendall_tau_rank_correlation_coefficient

Parameters:
recalc - Whether or not to recalculate this value if it has already been calculated.
Returns:
The Kendall tau correlation value.

getKendallCorrelation

public static double getKendallCorrelation(List<Double> x,
                                           List<Double> y)
Returns the Kendall tau rank correlation coefficient of the 2 sets of data. x = sample values of molecule 0 y = sample values of molecule 1 n = number of samples in each molecule Rx = the rank of the samples in molecule 0 Ry = the rank of the samples in molecule 1 concordant = The number of concordant pairs discordant = The number of discordant pairs concordant - discordant correlationValue = ----------------------------- (1/2) * pairs * ( pairs-1 ) Adapted from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kendall_tau_rank_correlation_coefficient

Parameters:
x - The first set of data to use for the calculation.
y - The second set of data to use for the calculation.
Returns:
The Kendall tau correlation value.

getRank

protected static int[] getRank(List<Double> array)
Returns the rank of each element, ie the new location of each element in the array if the array were sorted. Based on selection sort.

Parameters:
array - The arrayList to get the rank of.
Returns:
An array containing the rank order of each element.
